WordsClass.Definition: to leave somebody, especially somebody you are responsible for, with no intention of returning
able to do something (used as a modal verb) to have the skill, intelligence, opportunity, etc. needed to do something
a little more or less than; a little before or after
to respect somebody for what they have done or to respect their qualities
a room in which there is a bath/ bathtub, a washbasin and often a toilet
a device that is placed inside a car engine, clock, radio, etc. and that produces the electricity that makes it work
the first meal of the day
thick strong metal rope used on ships, for supporting bridges, etc.
to use numbers to find out a total number, amount, distance, etc.
cancel something to decide that something that has been arranged will not now take place
charge (for something) the amount of money that somebody asks for goods and services
costing little money or less money than you expected
he world; the planet that we live on
to put food in your mouth, chew it and swallow it
the relationship between production, trade and the supply of money in a particular country or region
to experience something, especially something unpleasant or difficult, while you are trying to do something else
to get pleasure from something
feeling or showing pleasure; pleased
solid, firm or stiff and difficult to bend or break
to put or keep somebody/something in a place where they/it cannot be seen or found
an area of land that is higher than the land around it, but not as high as a mountain
an illness that is caused by bacteria or a virus and that affects one part of the body
facts or details about somebody/something
the fair treatment of people
wanting to do something or wanting something to happen very much
to hit a door, etc. firmly in order to attract attention, to hit something, often by accident, with a short, hard blow
a piece of paper, etc. that is attached to something and that gives information about it
lack (of something) the state of not having something or not having enough of something
obey (somebody/something) to do what you are told or expected to do
a thing that can be seen and touched, but is not alive
a tube through which liquids and gases can flow
unhappy or showing unhappiness
a thick liquid that is eaten with food to add flavour to it
to frighten somebody
the flat surface at the front of a television, computer, or other electronic device, on which you see pictures or information

one of the two groups of elected politicians who make laws in some countries, for example in the US, Australia, Canada and France. The Senate is smaller than the other group but higher in rank. Many state parliaments in the US also have a Senate.
a member of a senate
connected with society and the way it is organized
a small round solid piece of medicine that you swallow
happening at the end of a long process
